content: Part of a series on[2010 Summer Youth Olympics](/wiki/2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics) - [Bid process](/wiki/Bids_for_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics) - [Venues](/wiki/Venues_of_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics) - [Mascots](/wiki/Lyo_and_Merly) - [Theme song](/wiki/Everyone_(Olympics_song)) - [Torch relay](/wiki/2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics_torch_relay) - [Medal table](/wiki/2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics_medal_table) (medalists) - [Event calendar](/wiki/2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics#Calendar) - [Chronological summary](/wiki/Chronological_summary_of_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics) - **[IOC](/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee)** - **[SNOC](/wiki/Singapore_National_Olympic_Council)** - **[SYOGOC](/wiki/Singapore_Youth_Olympic_Games_Organising_Committee)** - v - t - e The **[2010 Summer Youth Olympics](/wiki/2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics)**, the inaugural event of its kind, were celebrated in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) from 14 to 26 August 2010. A total of 3,531 athletes between 14 and 18 years of age from 204 [National Olympic Committees](/wiki/National_Olympic_Committee) (NOCs) participated at the Games in 201 events in 26 sports. A number of new events were held, including mixed-gender swimming relays, a single combined mixed-gender cycling event, and a number of [mixed-NOCs team events](/wiki/Mixed-NOCs_at_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics). To foster friendship among participants, teams were formed by athletes from different countries to compete, often on an intercontinental basis. There were such events included in [archery](/wiki/Archery_at_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics), [athletics](/wiki/Athletics_at_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics), [equestrian](/wiki/Equestrian_at_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics), [fencing](/wiki/Fencing_at_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics), [judo](/wiki/Judo_at_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics), [modern pentathlon](/wiki/Modern_pentathlon_at_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics), [table tennis](/wiki/Table_tennis_at_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics), and [triathlon](/wiki/Triathlon_at_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics), and a number of pairs in [doubles tennis](/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics) were formed by athletes from two different NOCs. In addition, some traditional events at the main [Olympic Games](/wiki/Olympic_Games) were modified, most notably in [basketball](/wiki/Basketball_at_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics), which was contested according to [FIBA 33](/wiki/FIBA_33) rules. A total of 623 medals for events (202 gold, 200 silver and 221 bronze) were awarded; in [judo](/wiki/Judo_at_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics) and [taekwondo](/wiki/Taekwondo_at_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics) two bronzes were awarded per event. Therefore, the total number of bronze medals is greater than the total number of gold or silver medals. Additionally there were ties for a gold medal and a bronze medal, both in swimming. On 15 October 2010 the IOC announced that an [Uzbek](/wiki/Uzbekistan_at_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics) silver medallist had failed a drugs test and had been disqualified, but no immediate decision was taken on whether to promote the next two athletes. Athletes representing [China](/wiki/China_at_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics) won the most gold medals (not counting mixed-NOCs events) with 30, and also won the most medals overall with 51. Athletes from 98 countries won medals at the Games. The most decorated athlete at these Games was [Tang Yi](/wiki/Tang_Yi), who won six gold medals in swimming. **Contents** 1. Archery 2. Athletics 3. Badminton 4. Basketball 5. Boxing 6. Canoeing 7. Cycling 8. Diving 9. Equestrian 10. Fencing 2. Field hockey 3. Football 4. Gymnastics*Artistic Rhythmic Trampoline* 6. Handball 7. Judo 8. Modern pentathlon 9. Rowing 2. Sailing 3. Shooting 4. Swimming 5. Table tennis 6. Taekwondo 7. Tennis 8. Triathlon 9. Volleyball 10. Weightlifting 11.
